title: PSA: Bullying teammates, WONT help us win the game..
body:
Stop saying snide comments like


> "Oh nice job Mid" After mid dies
> or 
> "Nice shot" After a teammate that's clearly playing poorly misses a skill shot.
> 

Its not helpful period  and definitely does not increase our odds of winning . If anything it just opens room to bickering, and the more time spent talking starts causing everyone to lose focus and its basically a snowball effect for the team, game play.

Plus im sure that person you keep saying rude things to is just going to feel worse if they haven't muted u yet.. 

Just please, if you **know** that you can easily get toxic type /mute all when the game starts, or something triggers you..


**EDIT**: It seems like i've started a toxic feud in these comments.. Im not going to silence myself because im speaking truth that has hurt your ego...

I agree with this. On the spirit of the topic i will share the story of one memorable game.

It was way back, cant even remember the season. It was the time that Yorick got his first round of nerfs, still stronger than today. I was playing Yorick against Olaf and had a field day. On our mid lane the exact opposite. Our Cass was having a huge trouble called Le Blanc. And by huge i mean 0/5 huge. Our jungler started flaming her. Out bot joined also. But then i offered her a lane swap. "Cass, Olaf  is pretty weak now. Want a swap so you can farm till you become a late game monster? I can handle LB pretty easily." 

So it happened. Next recall (sadly with another Cass death) we swaped. Since top was a playground for me and didnt had to recall for that time, i had the money and bought a Spirit Visage. Went mid and LB went ham on me bringing me to 30% hp. But 20 sec later i was full hp. This story continued. LB was bursting me, i was healing and farming happily. 5 minute later they made the decision to swap back. And so we did. The swaps went back and forth a couple times until we went back to Cass vs Olaf top.

Cass was having it easy top, since Olaf could not do anything to her. Her farm skyrocked and managed to snatch 2 kills. The game went on with me participating on scirmishes being the annoying neverdying meatshield. Since Cass was at that island called top and my team had a fed Yorick to fight with them, the complains dissapeared. Teambattles came and top laners joined the fights. Cass was finally a monster getting multiple kills. The teamfights were won clearly. The game was ours.


The moral of the story is that if i joined the flame squad, the game would go to hell. But instead i offered a solution. And that worked. After all it is a teamgame and we should play as one. I never flame, try to offer solutions and keep the team spirit up. After all i am a support main and have to rely on teamplay. It is not easy to fight 5 enemies, a lot harder if you have to fight your own team as well. Stay positive summoners.

PS: Muting is not a solution to the problem. Is a solution to the symptom. So while it helps, it is not an excuse for flaming.

I don't understand why there are negative comments in this thread. Op is right. Bashing your opponents for not doing well does not make them perform better than they already aren't. In fact, it does the complete opposite. You may have that small percentage of people who perform better if heavily criticized, but for the most part, your ally is only going to perform worse. Also, let's not forget the fact that they may be losing because their opponent is just better than they are. Not every game goes in your favor, and players need to learn to respect that.

It does not solve the fact that that player's teammate(s) is/are toxic. The issue here is the fact that players are are demoralizing their own teammates and then refuse to retain the blame for the loss (if the game goes sour).

Also, saying shit like "thank god that game is over. this [insert laner here] was such trash." or "I can't believe we won that game with this garbage [insert laner here]" if you win (or lose) is just not necessary. All that does is ruin that player's games that follow.
Its just the league community, trying to shine light on a very serious top will always come with backlash.

Just because you don't see/hear it, doesn't mean it does not exist.

The issue is actually the detachment from reality, to be fair. The only thing you ever have any actual control over is yourself. As cliche as that may sound to some it is absolutely true and in my experience very few people truly understand this. When you attempt to control someone elses behavior you are taking an inefficient and usually unproductive approach. The thing a person should be doing is controlling their own behavior. People will follow the lead of someone with respect. If you treat others with respect it is for more likely for them to assist and work with you. If you try and control others you by definition you do not respect these people because by trying to control them you inherently see them as objects and not other human beings. People do not like to be controlled and will instinctive rebel and lash out at those who try to do so. "Fight the Power" is not just a catchy phrase that many people identify with, it is a biological truth and even necessity. We are pre-programmed to behave in such a manner. So, to answer your question the real issue is that people don't understand their own behavior and how it affects others. Because of this you lose games. Understand that your behavior directly affects the outcome of YOUR game. When you become negative your team becomes negative. Lead by example or don't lead because if you cannot be an example you cannot be a good leader.

Edit: To be clear I should state (though I feel sad that I feel the need to state this clearly) - You can only control your behavior, it is a fallacy to think you can control another persons behavior, an illusion you perpetuate to yourself that only you believe.

I had a post like this, and I was told that being toxic helps teammates learn more than being nice, because people will remember better if it's drilled into their head.

*sigh* I didn't know how to respond to this.
Too many people blame their teammates, or hone in on one person to take all their frustration. These players need a timeout...but I fear we'd lose a solid 1/5 of the playerbase.

What's frustrating is players like me, who although I have been toxic in the past and have grown up a lot in that regard, genuinely try to help you. They give you advice to help you win lane, they suggest not making certain decisions and explaining why. 

But the actual action of missing a skillshot or dying to your laner is not what makes people flame usually. 

It's when you tell your blitzcrank to be patient with his Q, maybe wait till you get closer. But instead he consistently just throws his Q immediately when the enemy steps out of minions, or appears out of the fog of war.

It's when you tell your mid laner he should recall with how low of health he has because dying for a few more cs is not worth it.

Then, your blitz gets mad and does something silly like leaves bot lane and refuses to support bot lane anymore.

Then your mid is just tilted beyond belief and insists on having ganks rather than just chilling out and farming.

People need to be more patient, yes, not flame their team when they make mistakes. But those same people who miss the skillshot or die mid need to listen to players that genuinely want to win and know they can help you do that.

I agree, for sure. Helping other players and trying to help other players is how a community grows positively. 

However, I'm indicating the crowd of individuals that cave into the gamer rage and take it out on others. If I'm getting destroyed as an ADC and it's very obvious I'm doing poorly, a teammate saying I'm "garbage", like "this quinn" or "this MF", then going off on how I misplayed a fight (not giving actual advice, mind you) isn't going to help me. I know that I screwed up and that I can improve, but degrading me isn't going to suddenly make me tiers better or recover the Gold gap between teams.

Also, I seriously believe that the removal of TeamBuilder has led to more toxicity in uneven matchups. For example, it's difficult to improve myself as an ADC when my opponents (both ADC and Support) are at the level of my Jungle/Middle (which is where I'm better) - the other laners have more experience and comprehension of the lane.
